factoid: Anatole kissed Princess Mary's hand in the evening after supper when everyone was about to retire.
Princess Mary did not know how she found the courage to look straight into Anatole's handsome face as it came near to her shortsighted eyes.
Princess Mary looked straight into Anatole's handsome face as it came near to her shortsighted eyes.
Anatole turned from Princess Mary and kissed Mademoiselle Bourienne's hand.
Anatole's action of kissing Mademoiselle Bourienne's hand was not etiquette.
Anatole kissed Mademoiselle Bourienne's hand simply and with such assurance.
Mademoiselle Bourienne flushed.
Mademoiselle Bourienne gave Princess Mary a frightened look.
Princess Mary thought "What delicacy!"
Princess Mary wondered if Amélie (Mademoiselle Bourienne) thinks she could be jealous of her and not value her pure affection and devotion to her.
Princess Mary went up to Amélie and kissed her warmly.
Anatole went up to kiss the little princess's hand.
Princess Mary said "No! No! No! When your father writes to tell me that you are behaving well I will give you my hand to kiss. Not till then!"
Princess Mary smiled, raised a finger at Anatole, and left the room.
All separated, except Anatole who fell asleep as soon as he got into bed.
All kept awake a long time that night.
Princess Mary thought "Is he really to be my husband, this stranger who is so kind—yes, kind, that is the chief thing."
Fear, which Princess Mary had seldom experienced, came upon her.
Princess Mary feared to look around.
Princess Mary thought someone was standing behind the screen in the dark corner.
That someone was the devil.
The devil had a white forehead, black eyebrows, and red lips.
Princess Mary rang for her maid and asked her to sleep in her room.
Mademoiselle Bourienne walked up and down the conservatory for a long time that evening, vainly expecting someone.
Mademoiselle Bourienne was now smiling at someone.
Mademoiselle Bourienne was now working herself up to tears with the imaginary words of her pauvre mère rebuking her for her fall.
The little princess grumbled to her maid that her bed was badly made.
The little princess could not lie on her face or on her side.
Every position was awkward and uncomfortable.
Her burden oppressed her more than ever because Anatole's presence had vividly recalled to her the time when she was not like that and when everything was light and gay.
The little princess sat in an armchair in her dressing jacket and nightcap.
Katie was sleepy and disheveled.
Katie beat and turned the heavy feather bed for the third time, muttering to herself.
The little princess repeated "I told you it was all lumps and holes!"
The little princess said "I should be glad enough to fall asleep, so it's not my fault!"
The little princess's voice quivered like that of a child about to cry.
The old prince did not sleep.
Tíkhon, half asleep, heard the old prince pacing angrily and snorting.
The old prince felt as though he had been insulted through his daughter.
The insult was more pointed because it concerned not the old prince but his daughter, whom he loved more than himself.
The old prince kept telling himself that he would consider the whole matter and decide what was right and how he should act.
Instead, the old prince only excited himself more and more.

The old prince knew that if he told his daughter she was making a mistake and that Anatole meant to flirt with Mademoiselle Bourienne, Princess Mary's self-esteem would be wounded and his point (not to be apart from her) would be gained.
The old prince pacified himself with this thought.
The old prince called Tíkhon.
The old prince began to undress.
The old prince thought "What devil brought them here!"
Tíkhon was putting the nightshirt over his dried‑up old body and gray‑haired chest.
The old prince said "I never invited them. They came to disturb my life—and there is not much of it left."
The old prince muttered "Devil take 'em!" while his head was still covered by the shirt.
